government: There is no government structure. In many cases, family bonds predominate.

The government is run by a corporation. Ruling functions are assumed by a company managerial elite, and most citizenry are company employees or dependants. Examples of this are asteroid mines, corporate outposts, or resort-worlds.
The goverment is a participating democracy. Ruling functions are agreed upon by the citizens directly. Examples of this are collectives, tribal councils, and comm-linked consensuses.

The goverment is a self-perpetuating oligarchy. Ruling functions are performed by a restricted minority, with little to no input from the mass of citizenry. Examples include plutocracy, hereditary ruling, or a caste system.
The goverment is a representative democracy. Citizens elect officials to perform ruling functions. Examples may be republics or democracy.

The goverment is a feudal technocracy. Ruling functions are performed by specific individuals for persons who agree to be ruled by them. Relationships are based on the performance of technical activities which are mutually beneficial. Those with access to higher technology tend to have higher social status.
There is a captive goverment, put in place by an outside force. Examples may be a colony or recently conquered area.
The goverment is a Balkanisation. There is no central authority,  rival governments compete for control.
The goverment is a civil service bureaucracy. Ruling functions are performed by government agencies employing individuals selected for their expertise. An example of this may be Communism.

The goverment is an impersonal bureaucracy. Ruling functions are performed by agencies which have become insulated from the governed citizens. Examples may be a decaying empire, or entrenched castes of bureaucrats.

The goverment is run by a charismatic dictator. Ruling functions are performed by agencies directed by a single leader who enjoys the overwhelming confidence of the citizens. They may be an emperor, or revolutionary leader.

The goverment is run by a non-charismatic dictator. A previous well loved dictator has been recently replaced through normal means. Examples of this may be hereditary kingship, or a military dictatorship.

The goverment is a charismatic oligarchy. Ruling functions are performed by a select group of members of an organisation or class which enjoys the overwhelming confidence of the citizenry. An example would be a revolutionary council.

The goverment is a religious dictatorship. Ruling functions are performed by a religious organisation without regard to the specific individual needs of the citizens. Examples may be a cult, or a theocracy.
The goverment is a religious autocracy. The goverment is led by a single religious leader with absolute power over the citizenry. They may be a messiah figure, or even a powerful psionic.
The goverment is a totalitarian autocracy. Government is led by an all-powerful minority which maintains absolute control through widespread coercion and oppresion.

The technology level here is pre-stellar, they can reach orbit reliably and have telecommunications satellites. Computers are common.

The technology level here is pre-stellar. There are some permanent space habitats, and the've developed rockets capable of reaching other planets in the solar system, but colonising them is out of reach for now.
The technology level here is pre-stellar, they have early gravity manipulation making spaceflight easier and faster. They have the capability of colonising other worlds in their solar system.

The technology level here is high-stellar, black globe generators suggest a new direction for defensive technologies, while the development of synthetic anagathics means that the human lifespan is now vastly increased.

culture.11: This society is very sexist. One gender is considered subservient or inferior to the other.
culture.12: This society is very religious. culture is heavily influenced by a religion or belief systems, possibly one unique to this world.
culture.13: This society is very artistic. Art and culture are highly prized. Aesthetic design is important in all artefacts produced on this world.
culture.14: This society is very ritualised. Social interaction and trade is highly formalised. Politeness and adherence to traditional forms is considered very important.
culture.15: This society is very conservative. They resist any change or outside influence.
culture.16: This society is very xenophobic, they distrust outsiders and alien influence. Offworlders face considerable prejudice.
culture.21: There is a taboo in this society, a particular topic is forbidden and cannot be discussed. Travellers who unwittingly mention this topic will be ostracised.
culture.22: This society is very deceptive, trickery and equivocation are considered acceptable. Honesty is a sign of weakness.
culture.23: This society is very liberal, they welcome change and offworld influence. Travellers who bring new and strange ideas will be welcomed.
culture.24: This society values honour. One’s word is one’s bond, and lying is both rare and despised.
culture.25: This society is being in some way influenced by another, neighbouring world.
culture.26: The culture here is a merger of two distinct cultures, either in harmony or conflict.
culture.31: This society is barbaric. Physical strength and combat prowess are highly valued in the culture. Travellers may be challenged to a fight, or dismissed if they seem incapable of defending themselves. Sports tend towards the bloody and violent.
culture.32: The society is a surviving remnant of a once-great and vibrant civilisation, clinging to its former glory. The world is filled with crumbling ruins, and every story revolves around the good old days.
culture.33: The society here is degenerating, they are on the brink of war or economic collapse. Violent protests are common, and the social order is decaying.
culture.34: The society here is expanding and vibrant. Fortunes are being made in trade; science is forging bravely ahead.
culture.35: The society here is recovering. A recent trauma, such as a plague, war, disaster or despotic regime has left scars on the culture.
culture.36: This society is a nexus, members of many different cultures or species visit here.
culture.41: This society is a tourist attraction. Some aspect of the culture or planet draws visitors from all over the galaxy.
culture.42: This society is violent,  physical conflict is common, taking the form of duels, brawls or other contests. Trial by combat is a part of their judicial system.
culture.43: This society is peaceful, physical conflict is almost unheard of. The culture produces few soldiers, and diplomacy reigns supreme. Forceful Travellers are ostracised.
culture.44: There is an Obsession in this society, everyone is obsessed with or addicted to a substance, personality, act or item. This monomania pervades every aspect of the culture.
culture.45: Fasion is highly valued in this society. Fine clothing and decoration are considered vitally important in the culture, underdressed travellers have no standing here.
culture.46: This society is at war, either with another planet or polity, or is troubled by terrorists or rebels.
culture.51: Space travellers hold a unique position in this culture's mythology or beliefs, and travellers are expected to live up to these myths.
culture.52: The starport on this planet is more than a commercial centre; it might be a religious temple, or be seen as highly controversial and surrounded by protestors.
culture.53: News agencies and telecommunications channels are especially strange here. Getting accurate information may be difficult.
culture.54: The culture here interacts with technology in an unusual way. Telecommunications might be banned, robots might have civil rights, or cyborgs might be property.
culture.55: There is something strange about the lifecycle here, there might be a mandatory age of termination, or anagathics might be widely used. Family units might be different, with children being raised by the state or banned in favour of cloning.
culture.56: The culture has a distinct caste system. Travellers of a low social standing who do not behave appropriately face punishment.
culture.61: The culture has an odd attitude towards some aspect of commerce, which may interfere with trade. For example, merchants might expect a gift as part of a deal, or some goods may only be handled by certain families.
culture.62: This culture has an odd attitude to nobility. Those of high social standing have a strange custom associated with them; perhaps nobles are blinded, or must live in gilded cages, or only serve for a single year before being exiled.
culture.63: The culture has an unusual attitude towards intercourse and reproduction. Perhaps cloning is used instead, or sex openly discussed.
culture.64: Food and drink occupies an unusual place in the culture. Perhaps eating is a private affair, or banquets and formal dinners are seen as the highest form of politeness.
culture.65: Travel is frowned upon here, and those who leave their home are reviled.
culture.66: There is a strange conspiracy here, something strange is going on. The government is being subverted by another group or agency.

life-events.2: Sickness or Injury: You are injured or become sick. Roll on the Injury Table.
life-events.3: Birth or Death: Someone close to you dies, like a friend or family member. Alternatively, someone close to you gives birth (or is born!). You are involved in some fashion (father or mother, relative, godparent, etc).
life-events.4: Ending of Relationship: A romantic relationship involving you ends. Badly. Gain a Rival or Enemy
life-events.5: Improved Relationship: A romantic relationship involving you deepens, possibly leading to marriage or some other emotional commitment. Gain an Ally.
life-events.6: New Relationship: You become involved in a romantic relationship. Gain an Ally.
life-events.7: New Contact: You gain a new Contact.
life-events.8: Betrayal: You are betrayed in some fashion by a friend. If you have any Contacts or Allies, convert one into a Rival or Enemy. Otherwise, gain a Rival or an Enemy.
life-events.9: Travel: You move to another world. You gain DM+2 to your next Qualification roll.
life-events.10: Good Fortune: Something good happens to you; you come into money unexpectedly, have a lifelong dream come true, get a book published or have some other stroke of good fortune. Gain DM+2 to any one Benefit roll.
life-events.11: Crime: You commit or are the victim (or are accused) of a crime. Lose one Benefit roll or take the Prisoner career in your next term.
life-events.12: Unusual Event: Something weird happens. Roll 1D.

unusual-events.1: Psionics: You encounter a Psionic institute. You may immediately test your Psionic Strength and, if you qualify, take the Psion career in your next term.
unusual-events.2: Aliens: You spend time among an alien race. Gain Science 1 and a Contact among an alien race.
unusual-events.3: Alien Artefact: You have a strange and unusual device from an alien culture that is not normally available to humans.
unusual-events.4: Amnesia: Something happened to you, but you do not know what it was.
unusual-events.5: Contact with Government: You briefly came into contact with the highest echelons of the Imperium – an Archduke or the Emperor, perhaps, or Imperial intelligence.
unusual-events.6: Ancient Technology: You have something older than the Imperium, or even something older than humanity.

pre-career.2: You are approached by an underground (and highly illegal) psionic group who sense potential in you. You may test your PSI and attempt to enter the Psion career in any subsequent term.
pre-career.3: Your time in education is not a happy one and you suffer a deep tragedy; perhaps you become hopelessly addicted to drink or drugs, a failed romance leaves you in tatters, or a fatal accident involving a close friend shakes your confidence. You crash and fail to graduate.
pre-career.4: A supposedly harmless prank goes wrong and someone gets hurt, physically or emotionally. Roll SOC 8+. If you succeed, gain a Rival. If you fail, gain an Enemy. If you roll 2, you must take the Prisoner career in your next term.
pre-career.5: Taking advantage of youth, you party as much as you study. Gain Carouse 1.
pre-career.6: You become involved in a tightly knit clique or group and make a pact to remain friends forever, wherever in the galaxy you may end. Gain D3 Allies.
pre-career.7: Life Event. Roll on the Life Events table
pre-career.8: You join a political movement. Roll SOC 8+. If successful, you become a leading figure. Gain one Ally within the movement but gain one Enemy in wider society
pre-career.9: You develop a healthy interest in a hobby or other area of study. Gain any skill of your choice, with the exception of Jack-of-all-Trades, at level 0.
pre-career.10: A newly arrived tutor rubs you up the wrong way and you work hard to overturn their conclusions. Roll 9+ on any skill you have learned during this term. If successful, you provide a truly elegant proof that soon becomes accepted as the standard approach. Gain a level in the skill you rolled on and the tutor as a Rival.
pre-career.11: War comes and a wide-ranging draft is instigated. You can either flee and join the Drifter career next term or be drafted (roll 1D: 1-3 Army, 4-5 Marine, 6 Navy). Either way, you do not graduate this term. However, if you roll SOC 9+, you can get enough strings pulled to avoid the draft and complete your education – you may attempt graduation normally and are not drafted.
pre-career.12: You gain wide-ranging recognition of your initiative and innovative approach to study. Increase your SOC by +1.
